header.name: boost/proto/context.hpp
header.para: Includes all the context classes in the context/ sub-directory.

header.name: boost/proto/context/callable.hpp
header.para: Definintion of callable_context<>, an evaluation context for proto::eval() that explodes each node and calls the derived context type with the expressions constituents. If the derived context doesn't have an overload that handles this node, fall back to some other context.

struct.name: callable_eval
struct.purpose: A BinaryFunction that accepts a Proto expression and a callable context and calls the context with the expression tag and children as arguments, effectively fanning the expression out.

description.para: callable_eval<> requires that Context is a PolymorphicFunctionObject that can be invoked with Expr's tag and children as expressions, as follows:

para.programlisting: context(Expr::proto_tag(), child_c<0>(expr), child_c<1>(expr), ...)

struct-specialization.name: callable_eval
struct-specialization.purpose: A BinaryFunction that accepts a Proto expression and a callable context and calls the context with the expression tag and children as arguments, effectively fanning the expression out.

description.para: callable_eval<> requires that Context is a PolymorphicFunctionObject that can be invoked with Expr's tag and children as expressions, as follows:

para.programlisting: context(Expr::proto_tag(), value(expr))

description.para: The current expression
The callable evaluation context

struct.name: callable_context
struct.purpose: An evaluation context adaptor that makes authoring a context a simple matter of writing function overloads, rather then writing template specializations.

description.para: callable_context<> is a base class that implements the context protocol by passing fanned-out expression nodes to the derived context, making it easy to customize the handling of expression types by writing function overloads. Only those expression types needing special handling require explicit handling. All others are dispatched to a user-specified default context, DefaultCtx.
callable_context<> is defined simply as:

The Boolean metafunction is_expr_handled_<> uses metaprogramming tricks to determine whether Context has an overloaded function call operator that accepts the fanned-out constituents of an expression of type Expr. If so, the handling of the expression is dispatched to callable_eval<>. If not, it is dispatched to the user-specified DefaultCtx.
Below is an example of how to use callable_context<>:
With increment_ints, we can do the following:
A BinaryFunction that accepts an Expr and a Context, and either fans out the expression and passes it to the context, or else hands off the expression to DefaultCtx.

If Context is a PolymorphicFunctionObject such that it can be invoked with the tag and children of Expr, as ctx(Expr::proto_tag(), child_c<0>(expr), child_c<1>(expr)...), then eval<Expr, ThisContext> inherits from callable_eval<Expr, ThisContext>. Otherwise, eval<Expr, ThisContext> inherits from DefaultCtx::eval<Expr, Context>.

header.name: boost/proto/context/null.hpp
header.para: Definintion of null_context<>, an evaluation context for proto::eval() that simply evaluates each child expression, doesn't combine the results at all, and returns void.

null_context::eval

header.name: boost/proto/core.hpp
header.para: Includes the core of Proto. Not included are the contexts, transforms and debugging utilities.

header.name: boost/proto/debug.hpp
header.para: Utilities for debugging Proto expression trees

struct.name: display_expr
struct.purpose: Pretty-print a Proto expression tree.

description.para: A PolymorphicFunctionObject which accepts a Proto expression tree and pretty-prints it to an ostream for debugging purposes.

method.name: operator()
method.purpose: Pretty-print the current node in a Proto expression tree.

description.para: This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.
The ostream to which the expression tree will be written.
The starting indentation depth for this node. Children nodes will be displayed at a starting depth of depth+4.
The Proto expression tree to pretty-print
The ostream to which the output should be written. If not specified, defaults to std::cout.

header.name: boost/proto/deep_copy.hpp
header.para: Replace all nodes stored by reference by nodes stored by value.

struct.name: deep_copy
struct.purpose: A PolymorphicFunctionObject type for deep-copying Proto expression trees.

description.para: A PolymorphicFunctionObject type for deep-copying Proto expression trees. When a tree is deep-copied, all internal nodes and most terminals held by reference are instead held by value.

method.name: operator()
method.purpose: Deep-copies a Proto expression tree, turning all nodes and terminals held by reference into ones held by value.

struct.name: deep_copy
struct.purpose: A metafunction for calculating the return type of proto::deep_copy().

description.para: A metafunction for calculating the return type of proto::deep_copy(). The type parameter Expr should be the type of a Proto expression tree. It should not be a reference type, nor should it be cv-qualified.

function.name: deep_copy
function.purpose: A function for deep-copying Proto expression trees.

description.para: A function for deep-copying Proto expression trees. When a tree is deep-copied, all internal nodes and most terminals held by reference are instead held by value.

notes.para: Terminals of reference-to-array type and of reference-to-function type are left unchanged.

header.name: boost/proto/domain.hpp
header.para: Contains definition of domain<> class template and helpers for defining domains with a generator and a grammar for controlling operator overloading.

struct.name: domain
struct.purpose: For use in defining domain tags to be used with proto::extends<>. A Domain associates an expression type with a Generator, and optionally a Grammar.

description.para: The Generator determines how new expressions in the domain are constructed. Typically, a generator wraps all new expressions in a wrapper that imparts domain-specific behaviors to expressions within its domain. (See proto::extends<>.)

The Grammar determines whether a given expression is valid within the domain, and automatically disables any operator overloads which would cause an invalid expression to be created. By default, the Grammar parameter defaults to the wildcard, proto::_, which makes all expressions valid within the domain.

struct.name: default_domain
struct.purpose: The domain expressions have by default, if proto::extends<> has not been used to associate a domain with an expression.

struct.name: deduce_domain
struct.purpose: A pseudo-domain for use in functions and metafunctions that require a domain parameter. It indicates that the domain of the parent node should be inferred from the domains of the child nodes.

description.para: A metafunction that returns mpl::true_ if the type T is the type of a Proto domain; mpl::false_ otherwise. If T inherits from proto::domain<>, is_domain<T> is mpl::true_.
A metafunction that returns the domain of a given type. If T is a Proto expression type, it returns that expression's associated domain. If not, it returns proto::default_domain.

header.name: boost/proto/expr.hpp
header.para: Contains definition of expr<> class template.

struct-specialization.name: expr
struct-specialization.purpose: Representation of a node in an expression tree.

description.para: proto::expr<> is a node in an expression template tree. It is a container for its child sub-trees. It also serves as the terminal nodes of the tree.

Tag is type that represents the operation encoded by this expression. It is typically one of the structs in the boost::proto::tag namespace, but it doesn't have to be. If the Tag type is boost::proto::tag::terminal then this expr<> type represents a leaf in the expression tree.

Args is a type list representing the type of the children of this expression. It is an instantiation of one of proto::list1<>, proto::list2<>, etc. The child types must all themselves be either expr<> or proto::expr<>&, unless the Tag type is boost::proto::tag::terminal, in which case Args must be proto::term<T>, where T can be any type.
proto::expr<> is a valid Fusion random-access sequence, where the elements of the sequence are the child expressions.
Encodes the return type of expr<>operator(), for use with boost::result_of<>

returns.para: *this

Tag is type that represents the operation encoded by this expression. It is typically one of the structs in the boost::proto::tag namespace, but it doesn't have to be. If the Tag type is boost::proto::tag::terminal then this expr<> type represents a leaf in the expression tree.

Args is a type list representing the type of the children of this expression. It is an instantiation of one of proto::list1<>, proto::list2<>, etc. The child types must all themselves be either expr<> or proto::expr<>&, unless the Tag type is boost::proto::tag::terminal, in which case Args must be proto::term<T>, where T can be any type.
proto::expr<> is a valid Fusion random-access sequence, where the elements of the sequence are the child expressions.
Encodes the return type of expr<>operator(), for use with boost::result_of<>

returns.para: *this

header.name: boost/proto/fusion.hpp
header.para: Make any Proto expression a valid Fusion sequence

struct.name: flatten
struct.purpose: A PolymorphicFunctionObject type that returns a "flattened" view of a Proto expression tree.

description.para: A PolymorphicFunctionObject type that returns a "flattened" view of a Proto expression tree. For a tree with a top-most node tag of type T, the elements of the flattened sequence are determined by recursing into each child node with the same tag type and returning those nodes of different type. So for instance, the Proto expression tree corresponding to the expression a | b | c has a flattened view with elements [a, b, c], even though the tree is grouped as ((a | b) | c).

struct.name: pop_front
struct.purpose: A PolymorphicFunctionObject type that invokes the fusion::pop_front() algorithm on its argument.

description.para: A PolymorphicFunctionObject type that invokes the fusion::pop_front() algorithm on its argument. This is useful for defining a CallableTransform like pop_front(_) which removes the first child from a Proto expression node. Such a transform might be used as the first argument to the proto::fold<> transform; that is, fold all but the first child.

struct.name: reverse
struct.purpose: A PolymorphicFunctionObject type that invokes the fusion::reverse() algorithm on its argument.

description.para: A PolymorphicFunctionObject type that invokes the fusion::reverse() algorithm on its argument. This is useful for defining a CallableTransform like reverse(_) which reverses the order of the children of a Proto expression node.

function.name: flatten
function.purpose: A function that returns a "flattened" view of a Proto expression tree.

description.para: For a tree with a top-most node tag of type T, the elements of the flattened sequence are determined by recursing into each child node with the same tag type and returning those nodes of different type. So for instance, the Proto expression tree corresponding to the expression a | b | c has a flattened view with elements [a, b, c], even though the tree is grouped as ((a | b) | c).

header.name: boost/proto/generate.hpp
header.para: Contains definition of generate<> class template, which end users can specialize for generating domain-specific expression wrappers.

struct.name: default_generator
struct.purpose: A simple generator that passes an expression through unchanged.

description.para: Generators are intended for use as the first template parameter to the domain<> class template and control if and how expressions within that domain are to be customized. The default_generator makes no modifications to the expressions passed to it.
A Proto expression

returns.para: expr

struct.name: generator
struct.purpose: A generator that wraps expressions passed to it in the specified extension wrapper.

description.para: Generators are intended for use as the first template parameter to the domain<> class template and control if and how expressions within that domain are to be customized. generator<> wraps each expression passed to it in the Extends<> wrapper.
A Proto expression

returns.para: Extends<Expr>(expr)

struct.name: pod_generator
struct.purpose: A generator that wraps expressions passed to it in the specified extension wrapper and uses aggregate initialization for the wrapper.

description.para: Generators are intended for use as the first template parameter to the domain<> class template and control if and how expressions within that domain are to be customized. pod_generator<> wraps each expression passed to it in the Extends<> wrapper, and uses aggregate initialzation for the wrapped object.
The expression to wrap

struct.name: by_value_generator
struct.purpose: A generator that replaces child nodes held by reference with ones held by value. Use with compose_generators to forward that result to another generator.

description.para: Generators are intended for use as the first template parameter to the domain<> class template and control if and how expressions within that domain are to be customized. by_value_generator ensures all child nodes are held by value. This generator is typically composed with a second generator for further processing, as compose_generators<by_value_generator, MyGenerator>.
The expression to modify.

struct.name: compose_generators
struct.purpose: A composite generator that first applies one transform to an expression and then forwards the result on to another generator for further transformation.

description.para: Generators are intended for use as the first template parameter to the domain<> class template and control if and how expressions within that domain are to be customized. compose_generators<> is a composite generator that first applies one transform to an expression and then forwards the result on to another generator for further transformation.

struct.name: make_expr
struct.purpose: Metafunction that computes the return type of the make_expr() function, with a domain deduced from the domains of the children.

description.para: Use the result_of::make_expr<> metafunction to compute the return type of the make_expr() function.
In this specialization, the domain is deduced from the domains of the child types. (If is_domain<A0>::value is true, then another specialization is selected.)
Same as result_of::make_expr<Tag, D, A0, ... AN>::type where D is the deduced domain, which is calculated as follows:
For each x in [0,N) (proceeding in order beginning with x=0), if domain_of<Ax>::type is not default_domain, then D is domain_of<Ax>::type. Otherwise, D is default_domain.

struct-specialization.name: make_expr
struct-specialization.purpose: Metafunction that computes the return type of the make_expr() function, within the specified domain.

description.para: Use the result_of::make_expr<> metafunction to compute the return type of the make_expr() function.
If Tag is tag::terminal, then type is a typedef for boost::result_of<Domain(expr<tag::terminal, term<A0> >)>::type.

Otherwise, type is a typedef for boost::result_of<Domain(expr<Tag, listN< as_child<A0>::type, ... as_child<AN>::type>) >::type, where N is the number of non-void template arguments, and as_child<A>::type is evaluated as follows:

listitem.para: If is_expr<A>::value is true, then the child type is A.
If A is B & or cv boost::reference_wrapper<B>, and is_expr<B>::value is true, then the child type is B &.
If is_expr<A>::value is false, then the child type is boost::result_of<Domain(expr<tag::terminal, term<A> > )>::type.
If A is B & or cv boost::reference_wrapper<B>, and is_expr<B>::value is false, then the child type is boost::result_of<Domain(expr<tag::terminal, term<B &> > )>::type.

struct.name: unpack_expr
struct.purpose: Metafunction that computes the return type of the unpack_expr() function, with a domain deduced from the domains of the children.

description.para: Use the result_of::unpack_expr<> metafunction to compute the return type of the unpack_expr() function.
Sequence is a Fusion Random Access Sequence.
In this specialization, the domain is deduced from the domains of the child types. (If is_domain<Sequence>::value is true, then another specialization is selected.)
Same as result_of::make_expr<Tag, fusion::value_at<Sequence, 0>::type, ... fusion::value_at<Sequence, N-1>::type>::type, where N is the size of Sequence.

struct-specialization.name: unpack_expr
struct-specialization.purpose: Metafunction that computes the return type of the unpack_expr() function, within the specified domain.

description.para: Use the result_of::make_expr<> metafunction to compute the return type of the make_expr() function.
Same as result_of::make_expr<Tag, Domain, fusion::value_at<Sequence, 0>::type, ... fusion::value_at<Sequence, N-1>::type>::type, where N is the size of Sequence.

overloaded-function.purpose: Construct an expression of the requested tag type with a domain and with the specified arguments as children.

description.para: This function template may be invoked either with or without specifying a Domain argument. If no domain is specified, the domain is deduced by examining in order the domains of the given arguments and taking the first that is not default_domain, if any such domain exists, or default_domain otherwise.

Let wrap_(x) be defined such that:
If x is a boost::reference_wrapper<>, wrap_(x) is equivalent to as_child<Domain>(x.get()).
Otherwise, wrap_(x) is equivalent to as_expr<Domain>(x).
Let make_<Tag>(b0,...bN) be defined as expr<Tag, listN<B0,...BN> >::make(b0,...bN) where Bx is the type of bx.

returns.para: Domain()(make_<Tag>(wrap_(a0),...wrap_(aN))).

overloaded-function.name: unpack_expr

signature.type: lazy_disable_if< is_domain< Sequence >, result_of::unpack_expr< Tag, Sequence const >>::type const

description.para: a Fusion Random Access Sequence.

signature.type: result_of::unpack_expr< Tag, Domain, Sequence2 const >::type const

overloaded-function.purpose: Construct an expression of the requested tag type with a domain and with childres from the specified Fusion Random Access Sequence.

description.para: This function template may be invoked either with or without specifying a Domain argument. If no domain is specified, the domain is deduced by examining in order the domains of the elements of sequence and taking the first that is not default_domain, if any such domain exists, or default_domain otherwise.

Let wrap_<N>(s), where s has type S, be defined such that:
If fusion::value_at<S,N>::type is a reference, wrap_<N>(s) is equivalent to as_child<Domain>(fusion::at_c<N>(s)).
Otherwise, wrap_<N>(s) is equivalent to as_expr<Domain>(fusion::at_c<N>(s)).
Let make_<Tag>(b0,...bN) be defined as expr<Tag, listN<B0,...BN> >::make(b0,...bN) where Bx is the type of bx.

returns.para: Domain()(make_<Tag>(wrap_<0>(s),...wrap_<N-1>(S))), where N is the size of Sequence.

overloaded-function.name: implicit_expr
overloaded-function.purpose: Return a proxy object that holds its arguments by reference and is implicitly convertible to an expression.

header.name: boost/proto/matches.hpp
header.para: Contains definition of matches<> metafunction for determining if a given expression matches a given pattern.

struct.purpose: A wildcard grammar element that matches any expression, and a transform that returns the current expression unchanged.

description.para: The wildcard type, _, is a grammar element such that matches<E,_>::value is true for any expression type E.
The wildcard can also be used as a stand-in for a template argument when matching terminals. For instance, the following is a grammar that will match any std::complex<> terminal:
When used as a transform, _ returns the current expression unchanged. For instance, in the following, _ is used with the fold<> transform to fold the children of a node:

para.programlisting: struct CountChildren : or_< // Terminals have no children when<terminal<_>, mpl::int_<0>()> // Use fold<> to count the children of non-terminals , otherwise< fold< _ // <-- fold the current expression , mpl::int_<0>() , mpl::plus<_state, mpl::int_<1> >() > > > {};

description.para: An expression

struct.name: not_
struct.purpose: Inverts the set of expressions matched by a grammar. When used as a transform, not_<> returns the current expression unchanged.

description.para: If an expression type E does not match a grammar G, then E does match not_<G>. For example, not_<terminal<_> > will match any non-terminal.
An expression

struct.name: if_
struct.purpose: Used to select one grammar or another based on the result of a compile-time Boolean. When used as a transform, if_<> selects between two transforms based on a compile-time Boolean.

description.para: When if_<If,Then,Else> is used as a grammar, If must be a Proto transform and Then and Else must be grammars. An expression type E matches if_<If,Then,Else> if when<_,If>::result<void(E,int,int)>::type::value is true and E matches U; or, if when<_,If>::result<void(E,int,int)>::type::value is false and E matches V.
The template parameter Then defaults to _ and Else defaults to not<_>, so an expression type E will match if_<If> if and only if when<_,If>::result<void(E,int,int)>::type::value is true.

When if_<If,Then,Else> is used as a transform, If, Then and Else must be Proto transforms. When applying the transform to an expression E, state S and data V, if when<_,If>::result<void(E,S,V)>::type::value is true then the Then transform is applied; otherwise the Else transform is applied.

para.programlisting: // Match a terminal. If the terminal is integral, return // mpl::true_; otherwise, return mpl::false_. struct IsIntegral2 : when< terminal<_> , if_< is_integral<_value>() , mpl::true_() , mpl::false_() > > {};

typedef.name: condition
typedef.type: when< _, If >::template impl< Expr, State, Data >::result_type

typedef.name: which
typedef.type: mpl::if_c< remove_reference< condition >::type::value, when< _, Then >, when< _, Else >>::type

description.para: An expression
The current state
A data of arbitrary type

struct.name: or_
struct.purpose: For matching one of a set of alternate grammars. Alternates tried in order to avoid ambiguity. When used as a transform, or_<> applies the transform associated with the first grammar that matches the expression.

description.para: An expression type E matches or_<B0,B1,...Bn> if E matches any Bx for x in [0,n).

When applying or_<B0,B1,...Bn> as a transform with an expression e of type E, state s and data v, it is equivalent to Bx()(e, s, v), where x is the lowest number such that matches<E,Bx>::value is true.

struct.name: and_
struct.purpose: For matching all of a set of grammars. When used as a transform, and_<> applies the transform associated with the last grammar in the set.

description.para: An expression type E matches and_<B0,B1,...Bn> if E matches all Bx for x in [0,n).
When applying and_<B0,B1,...Bn> as a transform with an expression e, state s and data v, it is equivalent to Bn()(e, s, v).

struct.name: switch_
struct.purpose: For matching one of a set of alternate grammars, which are looked up based on an expression's tag type. When used as a transform, switch_<> applies the transform associated with the grammar that matches the expression.

description.para: An expression type E matches switch_<C> if E matches C::case_<E::proto_tag>.
When applying switch_<C> as a transform with an expression e of type E, state s and data v, it is equivalent to C::case_<E::proto_tag>()(e, s, v).

struct.name: exact
struct.purpose: For forcing exact matches of terminal types.

description.para: By default, matching terminals ignores references and cv-qualifiers. For instance, a terminal expression of type terminal<int const &>::type will match the grammar terminal<int>. If that is not desired, you can force an exact match with terminal<exact<int> >. This will only match integer terminals where the terminal is held by value.

struct.name: convertible_to
struct.purpose: For matching terminals that are convertible to a type.

description.para: Use convertible_to<> to match a terminal that is convertible to some type. For example, the grammar terminal<convertible_to<int> > will match any terminal whose argument is convertible to an integer.

struct.name: vararg
struct.purpose: For matching a Grammar to a variable number of sub-expressions.

description.para: An expression type expr<AT, listN<A0,...An,U0,...Um> > matches a grammar expr<BT, listM<B0,...Bn,vararg<V> > > if BT is _ or AT, and if Ax matches Bx for each x in [0,n) and if Ux matches V for each x in [0,m).
For example:
When used as a transform, vararg<G> applies G's transform.

struct.name: matches
struct.purpose: A Boolean metafunction that evaluates whether a given expression type matches a grammar.

description.para: matches<Expr,Grammar> inherits (indirectly) from mpl::true_ if Expr::proto_base_expr matches Grammar::proto_base_expr, and from mpl::false_ otherwise.
Non-terminal expressions are matched against a grammar according to the following rules:

The wildcard pattern, _, matches any expression.
An expression expr<AT, listN<A0,A1,...An> > matches a grammar expr<BT, listN<B0,B1,...Bn> > if BT is _ or AT, and if Ax matches Bx for each x in [0,n).
An expression expr<AT, listN<A0,...An,U0,...Um> > matches a grammar expr<BT, listM<B0,...Bn,vararg<V> > > if BT is _ or AT, and if Ax matches Bx for each x in [0,n) and if Ux matches V for each x in [0,m).
An expression E matches or_<B0,B1,...Bn> if E matches some Bx for x in [0,n).
An expression E matches and_<B0,B1,...Bn> if E matches all Bx for x in [0,n).
An expression E matches if_<T,U,V> if when<_,T>::result<void(E,int,int)>::type::value is true and E matches U; or, if when<_,T>::result<void(E,int,int)>::type::value is false and E matches V. (Note: U defaults to _ and V defaults to not_<_>.)
An expression E matches not_<T> if E does not match T.
An expression E matches switch_<C> if E matches C::case_<E::proto_tag>.
A terminal expression expr<tag::terminal,term<A> > matches a grammar expr<BT,term<B> > if BT is _ or tag::terminal and one of the following is true:

B is the wildcard pattern, _
A is B
A is B &
A is B const &
B is exact<A>
B is convertible_to<X> and is_convertible<A,X>::value is true.
A is X[M] or X(&)[M] and B is X[proto::N].
A is X(&)[M] and B is X(&)[proto::N].
A is X[M] or X(&)[M] and B is X*.
B lambda-matches A (see below).
A type B lambda-matches A if one of the following is true:

listitem.para: B is T<B0,B1,...Bn> and A is T<A0,A1,...An> and for each x in [0,n), Ax and Bx are types such that Ax lambda-matches Bx

header.para: Contains definitions for child<>, child_c<>, left<>, right<>, tag_of<>, and the helper functions child(), child_c(), value(), left() and right().

struct.name: is_callable
struct.purpose: Boolean metafunction which detects whether a type is a callable function object type or not.

description.para: is_callable<> is used by the when<> transform to determine whether a function type R(A1,A2,...AN) is a callable transform or an object transform. (The former are evaluated using call<> and the later with make<>.) If is_callable<R>::value is true, the function type is a callable transform; otherwise, it is an object transform.
Unless specialized for a type T, is_callable<T>::value is computed as follows:

listitem.para: If T is a template type X<Y0,Y1,...YN>, where all Yx are types for x in [0,N], is_callable<T>::value is is_same<YN, proto::callable>::value.
If T has a nested type proto_is_callable_ that is a typedef for void, is_callable<T>::value is true. (Note: this is the case for any type that derives from proto::callable.)

struct.name: is_aggregate
struct.purpose: A Boolean metafunction that indicates whether a type requires aggregate initialization.

description.para: is_aggregate<> is used by the make<> transform to determine how to construct an object of some type T, given some initialization arguments a0,a1,...aN. If is_aggregate<T>::value is true, then an object of type T will be initialized as T t = {a0,a1,...aN};. Otherwise, it will be initialized as T t(a0,a1,...aN).

struct.name: is_expr
struct.purpose: A Boolean metafunction that indicates whether a given type T is a Proto expression type.

description.para: If T has a nested type proto_is_expr_ that is a typedef for void, is_expr<T>::value is true. (Note, this is the case for proto::expr<>, any type that is derived from proto::extends<> or that uses the BOOST_PROTO_BASIC_EXTENDS() macro.) Otherwise, is_expr<T>::value is false.

struct-specialization.name: is_expr
struct-specialization.purpose: A Boolean metafunction that indicates whether a given type T is a Proto expression type.

description.para: If T has a nested type proto_is_expr_ that is a typedef for void, is_expr<T>::value is true. (Note, this is the case for proto::expr<>, any type that is derived from proto::extends<> or that uses the BOOST_PROTO_BASIC_EXTENDS() macro.) Otherwise, is_expr<T>::value is false.

struct.name: tag_of
struct.purpose: A metafunction that returns the tag type of a Proto expression.

struct.name: arity_of
struct.purpose: A metafunction that returns the arity of a Proto expression.

struct.name: as_expr
struct.purpose: A metafunction that computes the return type of the as_expr() function.

description.para: The as_expr<> metafunction turns types into Proto types, if they are not already, by making them Proto terminals held by value if possible. Types which are already Proto types are left alone.
This specialization is selected when the type is not yet a Proto type. The resulting terminal type is calculated as follows:

If T is a function type, let A be T &. Otherwise, let A be the type T stripped of cv-qualifiers. Then, the result type as_expr<T, Domain>::type is boost::result_of<Domain(expr< tag::terminal, term<A> >)>::type.

typedef.name: arg0_

struct-specialization.name: as_expr
struct-specialization.purpose: A metafunction that computes the return type of the as_expr() function.

description.para: The as_expr<> metafunction turns types into Proto types, if they are not already, by making them Proto terminals held by value if possible. Types which are already Proto types are left alone.
This specialization is selected when the type is already a Proto type. The result type as_expr<T, Domain>::type is T stripped of cv-qualifiers.

struct.name: as_child
struct.purpose: A metafunction that computes the return type of the as_child() function.

description.para: The as_child<> metafunction turns types into Proto types, if they are not already, by making them Proto terminals held by reference. Types which are already Proto types are returned by reference.
This specialization is selected when the type is not yet a Proto type. The result type as_child<T, Domain>::type is boost::result_of<Domain(expr< tag::terminal, term<T &> >)>::type.

struct.name: value

description.para: The raw type of the Nth child as it is stored within Expr. This may be a value or a reference

T const(&)[N] becomes T const(&)[N]
T[N] becomes T(&)[N]

R(&)(A0,...) becomes R(&)(A0,...)
T const & becomes T
T & becomes T
T becomes T

T const(&)[N] becomes T const(&)[N]
T[N] becomes T(&)[N]
T(&)[N] becomes T(&)[N]
R(&)(A0,...) becomes R(&)(A0,...)
T const & becomes T const &
T & becomes T &
T becomes T &
The raw type of the Nth child as it is stored within Expr. This may be a value or a reference

overloaded-function.name: as_expr

description.para: The object to wrap.

overloaded-function.purpose: A function that wraps non-Proto expression types in Proto terminals and leaves Proto expression types alone.

description.para: The as_expr() function turns objects into Proto terminals if they are not Proto expression types already. Non-Proto types are held by value, if possible. Types which are already Proto types are left alone and returned by reference.
This function can be called either with an explicitly specified Domain parameter (i.e., as_expr<Domain>(t)), or without (i.e., as_expr(t)). If no domain is specified, default_domain is assumed.

If is_expr<T>::value is true, then the argument is returned unmodified, by reference. Otherwise, the argument is wrapped in a Proto terminal expression node according to the following rules. If T is a function type, let A be T &. Otherwise, let A be the type T stripped of cv-qualifiers. Then, as_expr() returns Domain()(terminal<A>::type::make(t)).
This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

overloaded-function.name: as_child

description.para: The object to wrap.

overloaded-function.purpose: A function that wraps non-Proto expression types in Proto terminals (by reference) and returns Proto expression types by reference.

description.para: The as_child() function turns objects into Proto terminals if they are not Proto expression types already. Non-Proto types are held by reference. Types which are already Proto types are simply returned as-is.
This function can be called either with an explicitly specified Domain parameter (i.e., as_child<Domain>(t)), or without (i.e., as_child(t)). If no domain is specified, default_domain is assumed.
If is_expr<T>::value is true, then the argument is returned as-is. Otherwise, as_child() returns Domain()(terminal<T &>::type::make(t)).
This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

overloaded-function.name: child

description.para: The Proto expression.

overloaded-function.purpose: Return the Nth child of the specified Proto expression.

description.para: Return the Nth child of the specified Proto expression. If N is not specified, as in child(expr), then N is assumed to be mpl::long_<0>. The child is returned by reference. If the expression is holding the child in a ref_<> wrapper, it is unwrapped before it is returned.

requires.para: N is an MPL Integral Constant.

returns.para: A reference to the Nth child

overloaded-function.name: child_c

description.para: The Proto expression.

overloaded-function.purpose: Return the Nth child of the specified Proto expression.

description.para: Return the Nth child of the specified Proto expression. The child is returned by reference. If the expression is holding the child in a ref_<> wrapper, it is unwrapped before it is returned.

returns.para: A reference to the Nth child

overloaded-function.name: value

description.para: The Proto terminal expression.

overloaded-function.purpose: Return the value stored within the specified Proto terminal expression.

description.para: Return the the value stored within the specified Proto terminal expression. The value is returned by reference.

returns.para: A reference to the terminal's value

overloaded-function.name: left

description.para: The Proto expression.

overloaded-function.purpose: Return the left child of the specified binary Proto expression.

description.para: Return the left child of the specified binary Proto expression. The child is returned by reference.

returns.para: A reference to the left child

overloaded-function.name: right

description.para: The Proto expression.

overloaded-function.purpose: Return the right child of the specified binary Proto expression.

description.para: Return the right child of the specified binary Proto expression. The child is returned by reference.

returns.para: A reference to the right child

header.name: boost/proto/transform/call.hpp
header.para: Contains definition of the call<> transform.

struct.name: call
struct.purpose: Wrap PrimitiveTransform so that when<> knows it is callable. Requires that the parameter is actually a PrimitiveTransform.

description.para: This form of call<> is useful for annotating an arbitrary PrimitiveTransform as callable when using it with when<>. Consider the following transform, which is parameterized with another transform.

para.programlisting: template<typename Grammar> struct Foo : when< unary_plus<Grammar> , Grammar(_child) // May or may not work. > {};

description.para: The problem with the above is that when<> may or may not recognize Grammar as callable, depending on how Grammar is implemented. (See is_callable<> for a discussion of this issue.) You can guard against the issue by wrapping Grammar in call<>, such as:

para.programlisting: template<typename Grammar> struct Foo : when< unary_plus<Grammar> , call<Grammar>(_child) // OK, this works > {};

description.para: The above could also have been written as:

para.programlisting: template<typename Grammar> struct Foo : when< unary_plus<Grammar> , call<Grammar(_child)> // OK, this works, too > {};

struct-specialization.name: call
struct-specialization.purpose: Either call the PolymorphicFunctionObject with 0 arguments, or invoke the PrimitiveTransform with 3 arguments.

description.para: Either call the PolymorphicFunctionObject Fun with 0 arguments; or invoke the PrimitiveTransform Fun with 3 arguments: the current expression, state, and data.
If Fun is a nullary PolymorphicFunctionObject, return Fun()(). Otherwise, return Fun()(expr, state, data).

struct-specialization.name: call
struct-specialization.purpose: Either call the PolymorphicFunctionObject with 1 argument, or invoke the PrimitiveTransform with 3 arguments.

description.para: Let x be when<_, A0>()(expr, state, data) and X be the type of x. If Fun is a unary PolymorphicFunctionObject that accepts x, then type is a typedef for boost::result_of<Fun(X)>::type. Otherwise, it is a typedef for boost::result_of<Fun(X, State, Data)>::type. Either call the PolymorphicFunctionObject with 1 argument: the result of applying the A0 transform; or invoke the PrimitiveTransform with 3 arguments: result of applying the A0 transform, the state, and the data.
Let x be when<_, A0>()(expr, state, data). If Fun is a unary PolymorphicFunctionObject that accepts x, then return Fun()(x). Otherwise, return Fun()(x, state, data).

typedef.name: a0
typedef.type: when< _, A0 >::template impl< Expr, State, Data >::result_type

typedef.name: a0
typedef.type: when< _, A0 >::template impl< Expr, State, Data >::result_type

struct-specialization.name: call
struct-specialization.purpose: Either call the PolymorphicFunctionObject with 2 arguments, or invoke the PrimitiveTransform with 3 arguments.

description.para: Let x be when<_, A0>()(expr, state, data) and X be the type of x. Let y be when<_, A1>()(expr, state, data) and Y be the type of y. If Fun is a binary PolymorphicFunction object that accepts x and y, then type is a typedef for boost::result_of<Fun(X, Y)>::type. Otherwise, it is a typedef for boost::result_of<Fun(X, Y, Data)>::type. Either call the PolymorphicFunctionObject with 2 arguments: the result of applying the A0 transform, and the result of applying the A1 transform; or invoke the PrimitiveTransform with 3 arguments: the result of applying the A0 transform, the result of applying the A1 transform, and the data.

Let x be when<_, A0>()(expr, state, data). Let y be when<_, A1>()(expr, state, data). If Fun is a binary PolymorphicFunction object that accepts x and y, return Fun()(x, y). Otherwise, return Fun()(x, y, data).

header.name: boost/proto/transform/fold.hpp
header.para: Contains definition of the fold<> and reverse_fold<> transforms.

struct.name: fold
struct.purpose: A PrimitiveTransform that invokes the fusion::fold<> algorithm to accumulate.

typedef.name: sequence
typedef.type: remove_reference< typename when< _, Sequence >::template impl< Expr, State, Data >::result_type >::type

typedef.name: state0
typedef.purpose: An initial state for the fold.
typedef.type: remove_reference< typename when< _, State0 >::template impl< Expr, State, Data >::result_type >::type

description.para: The current expression
The current state
An arbitrary data

Let seq be when<_, Sequence>()(expr, state, data), let state0 be when<_, State0>()(expr, state, data), and let fun(data) be an object such that fun(data)(expr, state) is equivalent to when<_, Fun>()(expr, state, data). Then, this function returns fusion::fold(seq, state0, fun(data)).

struct.name: reverse_fold
struct.purpose: A PrimitiveTransform that is the same as the fold<> transform, except that it folds back-to-front instead of front-to-back. It uses the _reverse callable PolymorphicFunctionObject to create a fusion::reverse_view<> of the sequence before invoking fusion::fold<>.

header.name: boost/proto/transform/fold_tree.hpp
header.para: Contains definition of the fold_tree<> and reverse_fold_tree<> transforms.

struct.name: fold_tree
struct.purpose: A PrimitiveTransform that recursively applies the fold<> transform to sub-trees that all share a common tag type.

description.para: fold_tree<> is useful for flattening trees into lists; for example, you might use fold_tree<> to flatten an expression tree like a | b | c into a Fusion list like cons(c, cons(b, cons(a))).
fold_tree<> is easily understood in terms of a recurse_if_<> helper, defined as follows:

With recurse_if_<> as defined above, fold_tree<Sequence, State0, Fun>()(expr, state, data) is equivalent to fold<Sequence, State0, recurse_if_<Expr::proto_tag, Fun> >()(expr, state, data). It has the effect of folding a tree front-to-back, recursing into child nodes that share a tag type with the parent node.

struct.name: reverse_fold_tree
struct.purpose: A PrimitiveTransform that recursively applies the reverse_fold<> transform to sub-trees that all share a common tag type.

description.para: reverse_fold_tree<> is useful for flattening trees into lists; for example, you might use reverse_fold_tree<> to flatten an expression tree like a | b | c into a Fusion list like cons(a, cons(b, cons(c))).
reverse_fold_tree<> is easily understood in terms of a recurse_if_<> helper, defined as follows:

With recurse_if_<> as defined above, reverse_fold_tree<Sequence, State0, Fun>()(expr, state, data) is equivalent to reverse_fold<Sequence, State0, recurse_if_<Expr::proto_tag, Fun> >()(expr, state, data). It has the effect of folding a tree back-to-front, recursing into child nodes that share a tag type with the parent node.

header.name: boost/proto/transform/lazy.hpp

struct.name: lazy
struct.purpose: A PrimitiveTransform that uses make<> to build a CallableTransform, and then uses call<> to apply it.

description.para: lazy<> is useful as a higher-order transform, when the transform to be applied depends on the current state of the transformation. The invocation of the make<> transform evaluates any nested transforms, and the resulting type is treated as a CallableTransform, which is evaluated with call<>.

header.name: boost/proto/transform/make.hpp

struct.name: protect
struct.purpose: A PrimitiveTransform which prevents another PrimitiveTransform from being applied in an ObjectTransform.

description.para: When building higher order transforms with make<> or lazy<>, you sometimes would like to build types that are parameterized with Proto transforms. In such lambda-style transforms, Proto will unhelpfully find all nested transforms and apply them, even if you don't want them to be applied. Consider the following transform, which will replace the _ in Bar<_>() with proto::terminal<int>type:
If you actually wanted to default-construct an object of type Bar<_>, you would have to protect the _ to prevent it from being applied. You can use proto::protect<> as follows:

struct.name: make
struct.purpose: A PrimitiveTransform which computes a type by evaluating any nested transforms and then constructs an object of that type.

description.para: The make<> transform checks to see if Object is a template. If it is, the template type is disassembled to find nested transforms. Proto considers the following types to represent transforms:

Function types
Function pointer types
Types for which proto::is_callable< type >::value is true
make<T<X0,X1,...> >::result<void(Expr, State, Data)>::type is evaluated as follows. For each X in X0,X1,..., do:

If X is a template like U<Y0,Y1,...>, then let X' be make<U<Y0,Y1,...> >::result<void(Expr, State, Data)>::type (which evaluates this procedure recursively). Note whether any substitutions took place during this operation.
Otherwise, if X is a transform, then let X' be when<_, X>::result<void(Expr, State, Data)>::type. Note that a substitution took place.
Otherwise, let X' be X, and note that no substitution took place.
If any substitutions took place in any of the above steps and T<X0',X1',...> has a nested type typedef, the result type is T<X0',X1',...>::type.
Otherwise, the result type is T<X0',X1',...>.
Note that when<> is implemented in terms of call<> and make<>, so the above procedure is evaluated recursively.

struct-specialization.name: make
struct-specialization.purpose: A PrimitiveTransform which computes a type by evaluating any nested transforms and then constructs an object of that type with the current expression, state and data, transformed according to A0 through AN.

description.para: The current expression
The current state
An arbitrary data
Let ax be when<_, Ax>()(expr, state, data) for each x in [0,N]. Let T be result<void(Expr, State, Data)>::type. Return T(a0, a1,... aN).

header.name: boost/proto/transform/pass_through.hpp
header.para: Definition of the pass_through transform, which is the default transform of all of the expression generator metafunctions such as unary_plus<>, plus<> and nary_expr<>.

struct.name: pass_through
struct.purpose: A PrimitiveTransform that transforms the child expressions of an expression node according to the corresponding children of a Grammar.

description.para: Given a Grammar such as plus<T0, T1>, an expression type that matches the grammar such as plus<E0, E1>::type, a state S and a data V, the result of applying the pass_through<plus<T0, T1> > transform is:

para.programlisting: plus< T0::result<void(E0, S, V)>::type , T1::result<void(E1, S, V)>::type >::type

description.para: The above demonstrates how child transforms and child expressions are applied pairwise, and how the results are reassembled into a new expression node with the same tag type as the original.

The explicit use of pass_through<> is not usually needed, since the expression generator metafunctions such as plus<> have pass_through<> as their default transform. So, for instance, these are equivalent:
For example, consider the following transform that promotes all float terminals in an expression to double.

header.name: boost/proto/transform/when.hpp
header.para: Definition of when transform.

struct.name: when
struct.purpose: A grammar element and a PrimitiveTransform that associates a transform with the grammar.

description.para: Use when<> to override a grammar's default transform with a custom transform. It is for used when composing larger transforms by associating smaller transforms with individual rules in your grammar, as in the following transform which counts the number of terminals in an expression.
In when<G, T>, when T is a class type it is a PrimitiveTransform and the following equivalencies hold:
when<G,T>::result<void(E,S,V)>::type is the same as T::result<void(E,S,V)>::type.
when<G,T>()(e,s,v) is the same as T()(e,s,v).

struct-specialization.name: when
struct-specialization.purpose: A specialization that treats function pointer Transforms as if they were function type Transforms.

description.para: This specialization requires that Fun is actually a function type.

This specialization is required for nested transforms such as when<G, T0(T1(_))>. In C++, functions that are used as parameters to other functions automatically decay to funtion pointer types. In other words, the type T0(T1(_)) is indistinguishable from T0(T1(*)(_)). This specialization is required to handle these nested function pointer type transforms properly.

struct.name: otherwise
struct.purpose: Syntactic sugar for when<_, Fun>, for use in grammars to handle all the cases not yet handled.

description.para: Use otherwise<T> in your grammars as a synonym for when<_, T> as in the following transform which counts the number of terminals in an expression.

struct-specialization.name: when
struct-specialization.purpose: A grammar element and a PrimitiveTransform that associates a transform with the grammar.

description.para: Use when<> to override a grammar's default transform with a custom transform. It is for used when composing larger transforms by associating smaller transforms with individual rules in your grammar, as in the following transform which counts the number of terminals in an expression.

The when<G, R(A0,A1,...)> form accepts either a CallableTransform or an ObjectTransform as its second parameter. when<> uses is_callable<R>::value to distinguish between the two, and uses call<> to evaluate CallableTransforms and make<> to evaluate ObjectTransforms.
The current expression
The current state
An arbitrary data
Evaluate R(A0,A1,...) as a transform either with call<> or with make<> depending on whether is_callable<R>::value is true or false.

The current state
